image.altText: Debbie Hatumale-Uy standing in front of boxes stacked in a warehouse.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of thousands of businesses saw trade literally stall as the Optus outage put payment systems, internet services, phones and work-from-home set-ups out of action. Now, many are demanding compensation.

title.children: Hundreds of thousands of businesses lost money in the Optus outage. They want the telco to pay up

image.altText: A smart phone with the message "Emergency calls only - YES OPTUS" where their signal bars should be.

props.synopsis: It's the day after the Optus outage struck more than 10 million customers and impacted health, education, transport and many other services. The ABC's consumer affairs reporter answers your questions in our live blog.

title.children: With some users still reporting no internet after Optus outage, our consumer affairs reporter answers your questions

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I've just seen a report about Optus slightly upping its earnings. Singtel — the company that owns Optus — released its half-yearly results to the Singapore stock exchange today. It says the Australian telco's operating revenue was up by 1 per cent over the six-month period. Optus also added 167,000 new mobile customers in this time. According to Singtel's press release, an increase of 108,000 new prepaid mobile customers was driven by a strong performance by Amaysim — that's a mobile phone provider that operates on the Optus network. A press release posted to Singtel's financial results page features this quote from Optus chief executive Kelly Bayer Rosmarin: "Our customer-centric approach continues to drive positive engagement. "We will continue to work to delight customers who are looking for value, innovation and a great network experience." However, it's important to note that these figures are based on results for the six months until September 30. So these results don't take into account yesterday's situation.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Optus upped profits by 1 per cent in last reporting period

children.content: I've just seen a report about Optus slightly upping its earnings.
Singtel — the company that owns Optus — released its half-yearly results to the Singapore stock exchange today.
It says the Australian telco's operating revenue was up by 1 per cent over the six-month period.
Optus also added 167,000 new mobile customers in this time.

According to Singtel's press release, an increase of 108,000 new prepaid mobile customers was driven by a strong performance by Amaysim — that's a mobile phone provider that operates on the Optus network.
A press release posted to Singtel's financial results page features this quote from Optus chief executive Kelly Bayer Rosmarin:
"Our customer-centric approach continues to drive positive engagement.
"We will continue to work to delight customers who are looking for value, innovation and a great network experience."
However, it's important to note that these figures are based on
results for the six months until September 30
So these results don't take into account yesterday's situation.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Federal parliament has voted to set up a full inquiry into yesterday’s Optus outage, including the possibility of witnesses being compelled to appear. The Greens, Coalition and crossbench teamed up to establish the Senate inquiry, which will look at issues like compensation and what steps Optus is taking to prevent the outage from occurring again. It will also look at the federal government's role in the outage, including steps taken by the government and regulator ACMA on the day. Senate inquiries can in certain circumstances compel witnesses to appear. Government senators initially voted against the specific terms of the inquiry, but eventually allowed it to pass unopposed. It's separate to the review already announced by the government, and will report back by early next month. — Reporting by Tom Lowrey
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Federal parliament sets up rapid Optus inquiry

children.content: Federal parliament has voted to set up a full inquiry into yesterday’s Optus outage, including the possibility of witnesses being compelled to appear.
The Greens, Coalition and crossbench teamed up to establish the Senate inquiry, which will look at issues like compensation and what steps Optus is taking to prevent the outage from occurring again.
It will also look at the federal government's role in the outage, including steps taken by the government and regulator ACMA on the day.
Senate inquiries can in certain circumstances compel witnesses to appear.
Government senators initially voted against the specific terms of the inquiry, but eventually allowed it to pass unopposed.
It's separate to the review already announced by the government, and will report back by early next month.
— Reporting by Tom Lowrey

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: NSW Premier Chris Minns has called on Optus to compensate customers for the inconvenience caused by yesterday’s outage. Mr Minns said the telecommunications giant needs to "do something big" to keep its customer base and prove it is reliable. The premier says he is particularly concerned for "mum and dad consumers" and small businesses who had been let down in the last 24 hours. "I mean, I assume Optus expects its customers to pay on time and is pretty tough on its customers when they don't pay — the same rules should apply in reverse. "You've got a situation where a lot of people were relying on them to provide a service and it wasn't done in the last 24 hours. "For mum and dad consumers, this was a real body blow and they should be able to expect better service from Optus." — Reporting by Sue Daniel
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NSW Premier reckons Optus should compensate customers

children.content: NSW Premier Chris Minns has called on Optus to compensate customers for the inconvenience caused by yesterday’s outage.
Mr Minns said the telecommunications giant needs to "do something big" to keep its customer base and prove it is reliable.
The premier says he is particularly concerned for "mum and dad consumers" and small businesses who had been let down in the last 24 hours.
"I mean, I assume Optus expects its customers to pay on time and is pretty tough on its customers when they don't pay — the same rules should apply in reverse.
"You've got a situation where a lot of people were relying on them to provide a service and it wasn't done in the last 24 hours.
"For mum and dad consumers, this was a real body blow and they should be able to expect better service from Optus."
— Reporting by Sue Daniel

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Negotiations mediated by Qatar are ongoing to secure the release of 10 to 15 hostages held by Hamas in exchange for a 1-2 day humanitarian pause in Gaza, a source briefed on the negotiations said. The negotiations are coordinated with the United States, the source told Reuters, adding that the pause should allow Hamas to gather details of all civilian hostages and secure the release of dozens more. "The exact number is still unclear at this stage," said the source, who declined to be named. A separate Egyptian security source also said a 24-48-hour ceasefire or limitation of the main zone of operations was expected within the next week in return for a release of hostages. The US and other countries have stepped up pressure on Israel to get this done, the source said. Qatar, where several political leaders of Hamas are based, has been leading mediation efforts between Hamas and Israeli officials over the release of hostages. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qatar-mediated talks aim to release 10-15 hostages

children.content: Negotiations mediated by Qatar are ongoing to secure the release of 10 to 15 hostages held by Hamas in exchange for a 1-2 day humanitarian pause in Gaza, a source briefed on the negotiations said.

The negotiations are coordinated with the United States, the source told Reuters, adding that the pause should allow Hamas to gather details of all civilian hostages and secure the release of dozens more.
"The exact number is still unclear at this stage," said the source, who declined to be named.
A separate Egyptian security source also said a 24-48-hour ceasefire or limitation of the main zone of operations was expected within the next week in return for a release of hostages.
The US and other countries have stepped up pressure on Israel to get this done, the source said.
Qatar, where several political leaders of Hamas are based, has been leading mediation efforts between Hamas and Israeli officials over the release of hostages.
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The United Nations says the number of staff killed in Israel's operation in Gaza since October 7 has been the highest loss of life in the organisation's history. United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) representative, Dominic Allen delivered the numbers during a press conference in Ramallah in the West Bank, joined by Palestinian Health Minister Mai al-Kaila. "I would also like to pay respect and condolences to the over 10,000 lives that have been lost," Mr Allen said "That includes the 192 healthcare workers in Gaza and 89 UNRWA staff. It is the highest loss of life in the United Nations in one operation in our history. "Now, what we've seen through the last month, is more than a humanitarian crisis, it is a catastrophe. "And for UNFPA, we are deeply concerned for the 1.1 million women and girls in Gaza right now." He added that the key message from the UN is wanting a ceasefire, with WHO representative Richard Peeperkorn echoing the calls. Meanwhile, Ms al-Kaila called for "an immediate stop to the Israeli aggression on the Gaza Strip, and the West Bank" and for aid to be allowed through. "Especially fuel, to operate generators in the hospitals, and this should be urgently done and immediately, as well as allowing the access of voluntary medical teams to support the medical teams in treatment of those injured," she said "Allowing the exit of patients and injured residents to get treatment in Egypt hospitals and other countries without any hindrance. "The cease of displacement of people from their homes, and their neighbourhoods in Gaza. "All these demands are fair ones, and urgent demands to rescue those who can be rescued in the Gaza Strip."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Highest loss of life in the UN in one operation in our history': UN representative on Gaza war

children.content: The United Nations says the number of staff killed in Israel's operation in Gaza since October 7 has been the highest loss of life in the organisation's history.
United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) representative, Dominic Allen delivered the numbers during a press conference in Ramallah in the West Bank, joined by Palestinian Health Minister Mai al-Kaila.
"I would also like to pay respect and condolences to the over 10,000 lives that have been lost," Mr Allen said
"That includes the 192 healthcare workers in Gaza and 89 UNRWA staff. It is the highest loss of life in the United Nations in one operation in our history.
"Now, what we've seen through the last month, is more than a humanitarian crisis, it is a catastrophe.
"And for UNFPA, we are deeply concerned for the 1.1 million women and girls in Gaza right now."

Meanwhile, Ms al-Kaila called for "an immediate stop to the Israeli aggression on the Gaza Strip, and the West Bank" and for aid to be allowed through.

"Especially fuel, to operate generators in the hospitals, and this should be urgently done and immediately, as well as allowing the access of voluntary medical teams to support the medical teams in treatment of those injured," she said

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel's military spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari has claimed that Hamas has lost control of northern Gaza as thousands of residents have moved south. "We saw 50,000 Gazans move from the northern Gaza Strip to the south," Rear Admiral Hagari said in a televised briefing. "They are moving because they understand that Hamas has lost control in the north, and that the south is safer. "A safer area, where they receive medicine, water and food. They understand it's an improvement." Mr Hagari added that there would be no ceasefire but Israel has been allowing for humanitarian pauses at specific times to give residents an opportunity to relocate south. Meanwhile, Hamas says its fighters had inflicted heavy losses, with the armed wing on Wednesday releasing a video that appeared to show intense street battles alongside bombed-out buildings in Gaza City. Israeli tanks have met heavy resistance from fighters using underground tunnels to stage ambushes, according to sources with Hamas and the separate Islamic Jihad militant group. One clip from the Hamas video released on Wednesday showed fighters running past piles of debris and stopping to fire shoulder-propelled missiles at Israeli tanks. Another showed them shooting rifles from perches behind buildings and dumpsters. Reuters was not able to authenticate the footage. Saleh al-Arouri, an exiled Hamas commander, told Hamas-affiliated Al-Aqsa TV that Israeli forces may gain control of some areas in Gaza. "But that will not stop the resistance's fight against soldiers and tanks. The more (Israel) spreads and expands on the ground, the deeper its losses will become", he said. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli army says 'Hamas has lost control' in northern Gaza

children.content: Israel's military spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari has claimed that Hamas has lost control of northern Gaza as thousands of residents have moved south.
"We saw 50,000 Gazans move from the northern Gaza Strip to the south," Rear Admiral Hagari said in a televised briefing.
"They are moving because they understand that Hamas has lost control in the north, and that the south is safer.
"A safer area, where they receive medicine, water and food. They understand it's an improvement."
Mr Hagari added that there would be no ceasefire but Israel has been allowing for humanitarian pauses at specific times to give residents an opportunity to relocate south.

Meanwhile, Hamas says its fighters had inflicted heavy losses, with the armed wing on Wednesday releasing a video that appeared to show intense street battles alongside bombed-out buildings in Gaza City.

title.children: ASX rises, NAB lifts profit, Optus parent Singtel rebounds on upbeat profit results

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian shares are touching a three-week high in afternoon trade, buoyed by the gains in  financial stocks on bets the central bank was done with interest rate hikes for now, while National Australia Bank rose 1.2% after the lender reported higher annual cash profit. The ASX 200 index rose 0.7 per cent to 7,043 by 12:55pm AEDT, its highest level since October 19. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) lifted key rates to a more than 12-year high on Tuesday but said that going forward it would assess data more closely to decide if even more tightening was required. Analysts at UOB said the RBA's policy guidance in November was "dovish-sounding", adding they expect the RBA to keep rates unchanged in December. Banks rose 1.1 per cent, with three of the big four advancing between 1.3 per cent and 2.2 per cent. Westpac was down 1.8 per cent, as it was trading ex-dividend. Mining stocks also surged 0.6% tracking higher iron ore prices, after the central bank governor in top steel producer China spoke on ongoing support measures for the property market. Rio Tinto rose 0.8 per cent, while BHP added 0.7 per cent. Technology stocks slumped 2.9 per cent, becoming the biggest percentage losers on the benchmark. The sub-index was set for biggest drop in two weeks. Heavyweight Xero's shares fell as much as 9 per cent, as the software firm's half-year core profit missed analyst expectations. Wisetech Global shed 0.8 per cent, while shares of Block gained 2.8 per cent. Gold stocks also slipped 1.8 per cent following a drop in gold prices. Evolution Mining and Northern Star Resources fell 1.1 per cent and 0.4 per cent, respectively.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX hits three-week high, Xero falls 9 per cent

rose 0.7 per cent to 7,043 by 12:55pm AEDT, its highest level since October 19.

The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) lifted key rates to a more than 12-year high on Tuesday but said that going forward it would assess data more closely to decide if even more tightening was required.
Analysts at UOB said the RBA's policy guidance in November was "dovish-sounding", adding they expect the RBA to keep rates unchanged in December.
Banks rose 1.1 per cent, with three of the big four advancing between 1.3 per cent and 2.2 per cent. Westpac was down 1.8 per cent, as it was trading ex-dividend.
Mining stocks
also surged 0.6% tracking higher iron ore prices, after the central bank governor in top steel producer China spoke on ongoing support measures for the property market.
Rio Tinto
rose 0.8 per cent, while BHP added 0.7 per cent.
Technology stocks slumped 2.9 per cent, becoming the biggest percentage losers on the benchmark. The sub-index was set for biggest drop in two weeks.
Heavyweight
Xero's
shares fell as much as 9 per cent, as the software firm's half-year core profit missed analyst expectations
Wisetech Global shed 0.8 per cent, while shares of Block gained 2.8 per cent.
Gold stocks also slipped 1.8 per cent following a drop in gold prices.
Evolution Mining
and Northern Star Resources
fell 1.1 per cent and 0.4 per cent, respectively.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Some interesting numbers from CBA's economics team, which highlight just how much those trying to break into the market and those who have bought in the past few years are struggling. " Mortgage repayments as a share of income are currently the least affordable in the history of our analysis in all cities except for Brisbane and Perth," writes CBA economist Harry Ottley. "Median income data in the ABS employee earnings survey (which has a longer timer series) indicates repayments Australia-wide are approaching the levels seen in the late 1980s when the standard variable rate peaked at 17%. " Sydney is, as often, leading the way for expensive housing. "The difference between Australia's two most populous and usually most unaffordable cities, Sydney and Melbourne, is now the largest that it has been in this dataset," Ottley writes. "It is likely Sydney is approaching affordability constraints in terms of dwelling price growth. Our current dwelling price forecast for Sydney in 2024 is below that of the 8-capital city index." What's more, the CBA data overstates affordability, as it is based on a household of two full-time employees both earning average wages. "The average weekly earnings data is used in this analysis as it is the most high-frequency dataset that suits the calculation," explains Ottley. "Average earnings are skewed higher by high incomes and as such using median incomes would result in measures of affordability looking even more challenging."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Record low housing affordability in all cities except Perth and Brisbane

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Telecoms giant Optus has reported a 1.4 per cent annual operating revenue, led by growth in its mobile business, offsetting declines in the enterprise fixed business. The company said in a media release that mobile service revenue grew 3.4 per cent, with an increase in consumer preferences for lower priced prepaid offerings. This growth resulted from customer acquisition, higher postpaid ARPU as well as increased revenue from Optus' successful broadcast of the FIFA Women's World. In the first half, the total mobile customer base grew 167,000, with 108,000 new prepaid mobile customers driven by a strong performance by amaysim. However, its operating expenses were up 3.4 per cent, reflecting higher costs of goods sold and content costs, as well as inflationary pressure on expenses, especially energy costs. As a result, the telco's earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) declined 3.2 per cent whilst revenue minus expenses excluding tax and interest (EBIT) — a key indicator of profitability — declined 14 per cent. "Optus has made continued progress in delivering its strategy, despite challenging market conditions including weak consumer sentiment and inflationary pressures that have resulted in pressure on operating expenses," said Optus CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin. "Our customer-centric approach has continued to drive positive engagement. However, we recognise that yesterday's outage has let down our customers and for that we are truly sorry. We will continue to work even harder to retain our customers trust and to deliver great network experience, good value, and continued innovation."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Optus reports revenue growth but faces high operating expenses

children.content: Telecoms giant Optus has reported a 1.4 per cent annual operating revenue, led by growth in its mobile business, offsetting declines in the enterprise fixed business.
The company said in a media release that
mobile service revenue grew 3.4 per cent
, with an increase in consumer preferences for lower priced prepaid offerings.
This growth resulted from customer acquisition, higher postpaid ARPU as well as increased revenue from Optus' successful broadcast of the FIFA Women's World.
In the first half, the total mobile customer base grew 167,000, with 108,000 new prepaid mobile customers driven by a strong performance by amaysim.
However, its operating expenses were up 3.4 per cent, reflecting higher costs of goods sold and content costs, as well as inflationary pressure on expenses, especially energy costs.
As a result, the telco's earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) declined 3.2 per cent whilst
revenue minus expenses excluding tax and interest (EBIT) — a key indicator of profitability — declined 14 per cent

"Optus has made continued progress in delivering its strategy, despite challenging market conditions including weak consumer sentiment and inflationary pressures that have resulted in pressure on operating expenses," said Optus CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin.

"Our customer-centric approach has continued to drive positive engagement. However, we recognise that yesterday's outage has let down our customers and for that we are truly sorry. We will continue to work even harder to retain our customers trust and to deliver great network experience, good value, and continued innovation."

title.children: 'Huge mistake': NT government trying to recoup $500,000 after seniors' concession scheme bungle

image.altText: Composite of a man in army fatigues next to a blown up car

props.synopsis: Ukraine says it carried out a "special operation to eliminate" Mikhail Filiponenko, working "jointly with representatives of the resistance movement", while a purported Russian missile killed at least one after striking a civilian ship in Odessa.

title.children: Ukraine admits to car bomb killing of Russia-backed politician, Russian missile hits civilian ship in Odesa

image.altText: A woman in a family photo with other faces blurred.

props.synopsis: Jade Elizabeth Harrington has launched legal action against Queensland Health for allegedly unnecessarily removing her gall bladder and misdiagnosing a life-threatening complication of bariatric surgery on five occasions.

title.children: 'My husband even needs to assist me with showering': Brisbane mum sues Queensland Health and gastric surgeon for alleged negligence

image.altText: A woman wearing glasses smiling while standing in a park.

props.synopsis: Police allege Dee Folpp could have already been dead when they did a welfare check at a Muswellbrook unit before officers left and then returned later to find her body.

title.children: Alleged murder victim could have been dead for three days before body found

image.altText: Gamba grass fire

props.synopsis: Researchers are using 3D visualisation games to help people in northern Australia prepare for the  threat of fire and build resilience. This is how they work.

title.children: Playing with fire: How digital games help communities in northern Australia face the growing bushfire threat

image.altText: underwater shot of diver harvesting sea urchin

props.synopsis: When abalone diver Chris Theodore noticed sea urchins destroying his fishery he started harvesting the marine menaces as a culinary delicacy. Now a Senate inquiry wants to see the industry boom.

title.children: Can we solve one of the ocean's thorniest problems by eating it? These divers think so

image.altText: A diver in the water shining a light on a fossil.

props.synopsis: Hidden in watery chambers around South Australia's Limestone Coast are fossils telling the story of a prehistoric Australian world, which researchers are determined to find.

title.children: Divers uncovering secrets of Australia's megafauna past concealed deep in underwater caves

image.altText: Womens and men images cut out and put on a blue background.

props.synopsis: If you spend any time on TikTok, you've probably heard snippets of songs that sound like an alien consuming helium. This is called "nightcore" music and it's only getting more popular.

title.children: How a Norwegian school project turned into a TikTok trend that is changing the way new music is released

image.altText: Two South Asian women dressed in traditional Indian clothing

props.synopsis: This month, celebration is in the air for millions of Hindus, Sikhs, Jains and Newar Buddhists across the world who are observing Diwali — the Festival of Lights. But what about those who aren't religious?

title.children: Can atheists celebrate Diwali? These Indian Australians do it to feel closer to their culture

image.altText: The Marvels

props.synopsis: The Marvels, the latest film in the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU), is the first in the studio's history to feature three female leads.

title.children: The Marvels showcases power of teamwork as female leads break new ground

image.altText: A young Indigenous child wrapped in a towel sitting cross-legged on grass.

props.synopsis: In communities where high temperatures and stifling humidity are the norm, residents have been without community pools for years.

title.children: Pools begin to reopen in NT remote communities amid reports kids swim in croc-infested rivers
